description:
The sushi here was soo good! There was a wait when we came on a random week night, but they were kind enough to let us stand inside and order some sake while we waited. 

We got the assortment of sashimi, the Himalayan salt rock starter (amazing), and a roll. I would have preferred to hand pick my sashimi rather than get the assortment since some of the prices, like the Wagyu beef, really weren't that great. 

Really nice service and cute small space to get together with a friend.
author: Miranda N.

description:
Excellent sushi! Lived up to its hype. We waited about 20 minutes for 2 people. It's a small restaurant, seats maybe 16. Bar only.

Beastie Boys was heavenly. Hamachi Truffle was delicious. toro was melt in your mouth yummy. Salmon on Himalayan salt was pretty and tasted good. Not sure if worth the $20 but it was delicious. 

Everything we had was so tasty and pretty affordable. I also like that it's a family run establishment.

Service was great. The 2 women who were working weren't overly nice but I didn't care. I'm not there to get sucked up too, I'm there for the food. And it was worth it!

I'll be back for sure.
author: T L.

description:
Went to Elephant Sushi after hearing great things about it and although the food was good, the service was an absolute mess. 

We were one of the first customers in on a Friday night and we ordered our food before everyone else and that's about the extent of the good service. Our food came out after other people who ordered the same food as well as AFTER us. Not only that, but they failed to recognize one of the dishes we had ordered and simply left us waiting and didn't ask us how our experience and meal was until we flagged the waitress down (which should be easy to do given the small size, but bad service means they didn't recognize us.) The waitress still tried to pile the order on us and make us wait on it, so I had to explicitly mention I didn't want it.

Good to decent food, but not worth the terrible service and generally long wait.
author: Francis V.

description:
Have had Elephant Sushi bookmarked for years and the TL location's hours and I just never matched up. We found ourselves in Union Square, not having had dinner until late and I fired up Yelp, saw Elephant sushi nearby and IT WAS DECIDED. THIS WILL BE THE NIGHT.

We popped over around 8:30 pm, saw a couple waiting outside, the slender sushi bar packed (so much so the waitress took our names outside). We were quoted 30 mins, so we went across the street to grab a cocktail. By the time we ordered a drink, my phone started buzzing, so we pounded our drinks and went back. I guess we didn't have to chug, since the waitress said she'd hold our seats, but we wanted sushi ASAP!

We took the recommendations of our waitress and literally everything was fantastic. I've got some pictures here but doesn't do it justice. Suzuki carpaccio I think, himalayan trout, ya man roll, toro nigiri. I may swap out the toro next time (!) for something creative and more Elephant-y. I assume they've refined their menu to show-stoppers only, so I'd probably love anything I ordered. Some sake and beer. All in all, ~$125 I think for 2.

Again, VERY cozy seating -- I can see this being a problem if you're leggy, brought coats/bags, or have a need for personal space.
author: Vivian H.

description:
Had a great time here last night. Quality sushi with great value. Creative appetizers. The truffle hamachi was great and had shavings of black truffle over them. Uni was amazing, will definitely have to try the beastie boys next time.
We sat at the bar and the chef even gave us bonus items.
author: Charlie L.

description: This sushi is amazing (The White Out roll is amazing!), but the place is small. If you want no wait guaranteed, go right as this place opens. I would not recommend more than 2 people groups. You could bring a 3 person group but I would recommend that with people you're comfortable with as the place is close  All the seats filled up at 6:20 on a Sunday night but I think it can move quickly. You write your name down on the board.
author: Lily B.

description: My favorite sushi place in the city.  Worth the wait.  Love the atmosphere, the food and the staff is warm and welcoming.
author: Jerry H.

description:
Big name, tiny space. Large value, small (relative) prices. Huge flavor, few reasons not to go. 

Elephant is easily one of my favorite sushi spots in SF. This town has some great sushi, but it's mostly prohibitively expensive. Elephant hits that sweet spot between quality and value. 

The fish here is no joke. The cuts are generous, the quality is high, and the flavor treatments are dynamic. O-toro with caviar on top? Yeah. Seared butterfish? More please. Himalayan-salt-cured salmon? For sure. Scallops with yuzu? I do. I really do. The $40 omakaze plate has 16 slices of fish, and they're not small portions. The numerous $20 sashimi options have 5 solid slices of fish. Double the normal cut size of many alternative spots in town. And the offerings are very interesting flavor combinations. Oh, and the ginger seems to be pickled in-house. It's absurdly good.

The space is tiny - maybe like 12 seats total? So you'll likely be waiting unless you luck out and come at just the right time. It's all sushi bar, and all sushi. No izakaya food. The sake menu is very limited, and they have some beer. It's really all about the fish here, and the fish is very good. 

Drop in with your friend or small (very small) group, drop your name on the list, and go grab a drink somewhere. You'll be sitting and eating fish before you know it, and you will have zero regrets.
author: Don B.

description:
A last minute Sushi decision to have sushi in San Francisco, called ahead the Elephant Sushi and spoke to host as we were crossing the Bay Bridge. She would not take reservations but suggested we arrive before 7 pm. Arrived at the restaurant at 6:50 pm and got a street parking space right in front, so we were destined to dine there. Parking is always an issue around the Tenderloin and Union Square. The restaurant is tiny and only consists of a 13 seat sushi bar no tables. Two other parties ahead of us we waited about 15 minutes for our seats. 

The menu was limited but interesting.  We ordered the following items:

Sashimi omakase. 4 stars nothing fancy but a variety of thick pieces of fish.

Scallops 5 stars scallops stuffed into a tofu pocket with a light sauce.

Red and Yellow Roll 4 stars good size 

Sea bass 4 stars sliced sea bass with ponzu and fresh wasabi.

Spicy tuna "chips and dip" 4 stars spicy tuna and masago served on tortilla chips. 

Ocean trout Sashimi 5 stars The best ocean trout I have ever had served on a block of Himalayas salt no soy or wasabi needed. 

Service was good. The restaurant is tiny so by the time we finished there were at least an hour wait with more then ten people on the list. Parking depends on how lucky you are. The Korean restaurant next door catches a lot of this restaurant's overflow.
author: George F.

description:
My favorite sushi place in SF so far...

At the moment I end up here once a week, trying something new each time.

The Maguro Nigiri is a winner, but the butterfish (White Out or Walu Carpaccio) are new ones for me, and they are delicious. The Carpaccio melts in your mouth. Everything I've tried is really good.

Atmosphere is nice and cozy, it's small so you may brush elbows with your neighbor, but everyone is too busy enjoying the sushi to notice.
The seating is a long bar opposite the chefs, so you can get a small glimpse of the preparation, and the food comes over pretty fast. All enjoyed with a good selection of reggae music beating in the background.

There can be a bit of a wait to get in but they text or call when you're up. Once you add your name to the list, I recommend grabbing a drink at Rum and Sugar, 5 mins along Geary, while you wait.

Next on the list is to try the Omekaze Sashimi, then I'll give it a rest!
author: Cassandra G.

description:
Elephant Sushi is one of my favorite sushi places in San Francisco.

The restaurant itself is really small, so I would not recommend eating here with a party larger than 2 or 3. Luckily for me, I've never had to wait longer than 15 mins to eat here, but I always come expecting a wait because of the size of the place.

Service and the food have always been great. Some of my favorite items are:  hamachi truffle, walu carpaccio, white out, spicy hamachi, and the himalayan trout.

But really, I don't think you can go wrong with anything on the menu! I can't wait for my next visit here! :-)
author: Vu P.

description:
Saucy sushi place. 

This place is very small located NEXT to the corner bar on Geary St.. I almost missed it, thinking that the corner bar is the sushi place. It has a line set up outside the door and the door has a red circle handle. I guess sometimes they can get busy too. The restaurant is extremely small with only about 20 or less seats around the bar. 

We ordered the Hon Maguro, sake, ocean trout, scallop nigiris and the white out roll. Here's why it's two stars, they put sauce on everything and all things making it extra salty, but the fish quality is still A-okay/meh. 

Hon Maguro - came with sauce mixed with but the sauce is just drenched with oil. I mean a shit ton on it which I really didn't expect and yes it did say sesame oil and olive oil but all I taste is the oil. The sauce should be there to enhance the flavor not to cover the flavor of the fish. 

Nigiris - the nigiri already came with soy sauce or similar sauce and yet again drowned in the sauce. Every piece of the rice is just.... drenched and salty. Cannot TASTE ANY FISH BUT THE SAUCE. Then comes to scallop nigiri with NO sauce but wasabi inside, but I can tell the scallop was a-okay quality. 

White out - A okay but dry no sauce/flavor, not even wasabi was given on the plate so we asked them for some. Fish quality meeeeh, did not taste the butter fish when it already got torched.

Homemade Ginger - I give them props for doing their homemade ginger, but I feel like it's not pickled enough to pair with the dishes. Again, flavor is just not there. 

2 stars - 1 for the a-okay scallop and the other for the friendly service.
author: Maria H.

description:
Elephant Sushi no longer deserves a spot on my comeback list when I visit San Francisco. How I lusted after it! During my last trip here, a few different things marred my experience:

1. I was a solo diner, and was given a wait time of 15-20 minutes. I pop into a bar next door, order a drink, and immediately received a call that my seat was ready.

2. I ordered the white out roll, Alaskan trout and beastie boys. After the first two came out (and there was a considerable pause between the two dishes), the waitress cleared my plate and put down the check. I was like, wat. Where's my beastie boys?

3. It finally arrived, and man, this is not nearly as good as I remembered. The uni left a fishy taste in my mouth for the rest of the night until I found some Oreos to wash it off. The white out roll was not bad, but I think I remembered the escolar fish being torched even more so there was a greater contrast between that and the yellowtail inside. The Himalayan trout was okay, it's not nearly as melt in the mouth as much of these other reviewers seem to purport.

4. I would have been ok with the unstable, backless stools and zero elbow room if the food was good. But it just isn't worth it for me anymore.
author: Jin C.

description:
A non-traditional sushi experience for a reasonable price. Came here 15 minutes before opening on a Friday night. There was only one other group in line so we got a seat at the bar, no problem.

The White Out was the first roll we got and was a great opener. Everything was super fresh and the torched fish on top gave it a lovely smoky note. The Ya Man was definitely our favorite - the fried onions gave it a satisfying crunch and the olive oil in the pesto paired surprisingly well with the rest of the ingredients. I thought the Red & Yellow was a bit overly sweet with both the mango and the soy glaze, but my partner liked it a lot.

We also got the Hotate and Hamachi nigiri. Both pieces were quite generous in size, but the Hotate was definitely more memorable because of the sweet and delicate scallop.

All in all we left full but not stuffed. We spent around $70 for two, which I thought was fair for the quantity of food and the level of creativity that you can't find in your average sushi spot. Plus, the staff were super nice and attentive. Would return!
author: Joanna X.

description:
If there was ever such a thing as orgasmic sushi, this would be it. I met up with Nina Y. for dinner and waited about 30-45 minutes in line to get into this tiny restaurant. Be prepared if it's chilly outside! I wish they had someone roaming the line (or signs at least) to tell people that they need to go inside first to get onto the list.

Anyways, we finally got inside and were ready to order, since we decided while waiting what we wanted. They weren't in any hurry despite the line. We felt welcome and well-served. We split the Hamachi Truffle, which melted in our mouths. So good. It's a must-try.

We also shared what I believe were the White Out and Spicy Hamachi rolls. Both were insanely fresh. Also melted in our mouths. They were also packed with ingredients so we left feeling content. There was probably some room for dessert, but we decided on a night cap elsewhere instead. 

I'd definitely want to come back here, even though there are so many other sushi places to try. They make some of the best sushi I've ever had. Next time I'll savor the moments by ordering some sake or an extra appetizer. Plus there are tons of bars around to fill in your time spent in this "scenic" neighborhood.
author: Stefanie C.

description:
4.5 Stars. I really wish we could give half star ratings. 

Elephant sushi -- my favorite sushi experience in SF so far, although I must admit I haven't had many. Many factors play into this rating: 

1) We were near the front of the line when it opened so no waiting for us. Oh, how I hate waiting for food... 

2) I was not on a blind date or first date = the company I kept was amazing. 

3) The food was great. There was none of this over sriracha mayo'ed roll that's been haunting the sushi scene in recent years. The plates were pleasing yet simple to the eye. My favorite dish we ordered is the omakase. We also ordered the ya man roll and the yummy pocket. 

We went to the Geary street location and the place was so small, I was transported back to Japan where restaurants are tiny and lines are long. Hah. 

A pleasant experience, but maybe things would have been different I had to wait for my food. :D
author: Melanie E.

description:
Came here on New Years Eve. (FYI There is more than one location- make sure you meet your friends at the correct one) 

Hours are limited, seats are even more limited, maybe 12? Sign in and wait outside, the place is tiny. 

That said, I highly recommend it. Get the Himalayan Trout!! Whatever you do, don't miss that. We also had a couple rolls that were good and the basil salmon. But the Trout was crave worthy, return necessary! They had a nice wine list and sake as well.
author: Kristen M.

description:
The best sushi I have had in a LONG LONG time. Loved every single roll I ordered. The prices were also super reasonable for being a 15 stool sushi joint. 

The atmosphere was upbeat and relaxing at the same time. It's a small space but did not feel cramped. 

The fish was absolutely perfect and the tuna just melted. I am only here visiting but when I come back to San Francisco, I will 100% come back. 

FYI - get here when they open so you don't have to wait.
author: Adam S.

description:
This used to be one of our favorite sushi places in SF and we went pretty often but went again last week and service was a mess.

Our tea came 30mins after we ordered, first dish took 45mins, then they got confused who ordered what and gave our second dish to some next door bartender (I think) who came in to say hi. Gave the wrong check to the party next to us. Nothing went right during our dinner. Left feeling really frustrated.  No longer worth the long wait.
author: Dana C.

description: Excellent. Tried the Giants roll, suzuki nigiri and tuna nigiri. Fresh fish, no nonsene (tiny) interior. Go here for a quick meal to focus on the fish, and nothing else. I'm a novice with SF sushi spots but this would be one of the best sushi options back in Boston. Prices were reasonable, all three dishes came out to $30, and the wait was only 10 minutes on a sunday night but call ahead to double check.
author: Riley S.

description:
5 stars just for the trout! The fish was super fresh and tender and I loved that it was served on a Himalayan salt brick. It gives you the perfect about of saltiness. No need for soy sauce here! Even with their toppings and sauces on the trout, it didn't hide the taste of the fish. It was so soft that it did feel like it melted in my mouth. This is a highly recommended item!

I also got the ya man roll which had salmon on top and fried onions and avocado inside. I'm allergic to avocado so I was able to sub it with cucumbers. The salmon was a bit thin and the fried onions really took over in flavor. Maybe the avocado would have balanced the flavor out better. Not a bad roll though, still good. 

When my friends and I picked this place to eat, we didn't realize it was a bar seating style with limited seats so we had to wait a bit. Luckily there was a bar next door and the host told us he would call or come get us when our seats were available. And he did come get us, which was really nice. I noticed a couple got called for their reservations too while we were waiting in the bar. 

Service was pretty fast and the waitress and host are real attentive with refilling our waters or other requests. The ambiance is nice and modern but you do hear a lot of police and ambulance sirens with the restaurant located in the tenderloin. After our meal, we got ice cream down the block and was eating it outside. We saw our host walk by, assuming this was after his shift was over, and he waved and said hi to us. I thought that was really kind of him. Nice attitude inside AND outside of work!
author: Teri C.

description: I went on a Sunday evening, and didn't have to wait long despite the size of the restaurant. I got the yummy pocket and spicy trio sashimi bowl. The fish was incredibly fresh. My friends got several different rolls and the king salmon on himalayan pink salt rock, and they loved it. I would definitely recommend this place.
author: Stacy L.

description:
If you've seen the film "Contact", you'll know there's a scene where Jodie Foster's character is so overwhelmed with the intrinsic beauty of the cosmos that she can only just manage to say "no words; they should have sent a poet".

That's how I feel about my hour at Elephant Sushi. Life will never be the same.

I like sushi. I have had a lot of what I thought was good sushi at home in London. I have watched videos on YouTube of how to properly eat sushi (for example, turn nigiri on its side so you dip the fish in the soy sauce, not the rice, never the rice). 

I had assorted sashimi (8 pieces), Himalayan trout (4 pieces) and Alaska roll (6 pieces) and an Asahi beer.

Maybe I'll just copy over the stream of consciousness WhatsApp messages I wrote to a friend back home:

18:27 This is by a really wide margin the best sushi I've ever had

18:27 It's not even close

18:34 I had no idea it could be this good

18:36 This is exceptional

18:36 Also people around me don't know how to eat sushi

18:36 To my right they mixed the soy sauce and the wasabi

18:37 To my left they soaked the sashimi in the soy and ate it in bits off the chopsticks

(I'm judgemental af, so sue me)

18:41 There's a very light truffle oil on the tuna

18:41 It works so well

18:42 I'm done

18:42 That was life-changing

18:42 Like I could almost cry that was so good

So yeah, it's good. It's also really tiny, everyone who got a seat for the first cover of the evening was queueing outside before the place opened. 

Finally it all came to $67.27 not including tip. Not cheap at all but worth it. You might like to pre-eat if you're worried though. Maybe post-eat so you enjoy the sushi more. Just have some extra food available so you don't get carried away is what I'm saying.

Elephant Sushi: go there.

(PS I know you enjoyed my WhatsApp log, so I've given you another one below to another friend. You're welcome)

18:56 I just had life changing good sushi

18:56 Like, I didn't know it could be that good

18:56 Life feels better

18:57 Everything is good in the world

18:58 Sweet Jesus

18:58 Things will never be the same

18:58 That was astonishing

Also turns out that Jose Foster analogy wasn't great - I had plenty of words after all, but still none of them poetry.
author: Michael A.

description:
I just don't understand the hype. Came here with my girlfriend on a rainy night hoping to get our sushi fix. My girlfriend is from Hawaii where the fish is freshest, but I'm from here, so together we feel some type of way about our sushi. And believe me, we are willing to pay for that good good. 

Enter Elephant Sushi.

So I know that the whole only-fit-9-people thing is all the rage... let me take a step back. If there is a checklist of the new hipster establishments, where the restaurant is beautiful, the food is presented in such a way that angels sing, it's a tiny exclusive experience, and it's all over social media, and in addition, the food is just... meh. Well.. if that list existed, which it does, then Elephant Sushi fits the bill (and charges it too). 

It's too expensive. If the sushi was just a little bit cheaper, then maybe they'd get another star. The most important part of sushi is the fish, if you take away the capers and Himalayan salt block, you're left with fish. And this place fell short.
author: Anthony G.

description:
This place is fusion sushi done right, not like that weird kind where they put cream cheese or sriracha inside and somehow manage to ruin sushi... This place does none of that! Solid fish selection, creative use of flavors, and great options for all appetites, this place will definitely satisfy your sushi craving.

Elephant Sushi is located in Lower Nob Hill in a tiny little location with only 12-18 seats. Since it's tiny and popular, expect to wait in line if you don't show up early!

Here's what to order:
- Walu (butter fish) carpaccio is smooth and buttery, with a light truffle flavor and grilled onions for taste
- White Out is a sushi roll featuring the same buttery truffle flavored fish, it's smooth and melty and unlike any roll you've had before
- Salmon is a standout here as well. Get it in a roll (Ya Man is a good one), as sashimi slices on a platter of Himalayan salt, or in a sashimi bowl if you're extra hungry

Sushi rolls are delicious and creative, and the sashimi bowls are a good choice to round out the meal if sushi doesn't fill you up.

Staff is friendly and helpful, and the dining atmosphere is pleasant and cosy. Only annoying thing (besides the long wait) is they start their tip suggestions at 20% (ranging up to 30%), which definitely seems to be on the high side.

Great place to get your sushi fix, just make sure to show up earlier to avoid the line!
author: Brittany C.

description:
A friend of mine picked Elephant Sushi for dinner as he had heard good things about it so we landed up here a couple of days ago. Elephant Sushi is a small counter seating only (I think, but I could be wrong) restaurant in the hood (Tenderloin). At around 6 pm the first seating was already full and there were a couple of people on the list for the second seating which was to start after about 45-50 minutes. We put our names down, provided a number to be contacted on and dutifully made our way to the RxBar next door to down a couple of beers. 

We were seated at the end of the bar that is used to go behind counter, one of the worst places to be seated at the bar. The setup of the restaurant is that even though you are seated at the bar there is no interaction with the sushi chef. You give your order to the server who relays it to the chef and then delivers it to you. You might as well be sitting comfortably at a table rather than on a half stool in front of the bar.

Anyway as soon as you are seated they start you off with a free Walu Carpaccio ($16) which is butterfish topped with garlic, ponzu and truffle oil. This was so good that we ordered another round of the same later that night. After the first round it is honestly a blur. We ordered multiple rounds of sushi, rolls and sashimi all washed down with Kirin ($8), till we were stuffed. My take is that the fish was good but it was a little over-sauced for my liking. The rolls could have been made a little better as they seemed to fall apart but the rice used was of excellent quality. Service could have been a little more attentive, but it was not bad. Overall, it was a pretty enjoyable experience.

Damage seemed to be close to $$$ per person with tip, but we did order a lot of the good stuff. Price seems to be slightly higher when compared with other $$ sushi places in downtown. When weighed with the quality of the sushi, cramped seating, average service, I was not overly impressed, so don't mind returning but am not actively planning for it.
author: Ahmad J.

description: Really excellent sushi, and myself and a friend easily found seating less than 1 hour after they opened on a weeknight, but there was a line when we left. Toro and Sake nigiri were quite good and also tried the giant roll which was fun. Definitely worth a try to get in!
author: Kiki D.

description:
Been here twice and thought I owe this place a review.
 
This place is small, intimate, and friendly.   We arrived 5 minutes before the restaurant opens and there were about 20 people ahead of us. We were quickly seated.

Expect to pay premium bc this place is expensive, food is delicious and has great customer service.

We enjoyed every dishes that we ordered.

2 orders of uni rolls. Let's just say every bite including the rice was to die for. Highly recommended.

Hamachi sashimi: the cut is thinly sliced and you can taste how fresh it is.

Spicy tuna and chip:  the dish is too salty with out the chips. Very tasty and enough spice kick to it.

Rainbow roll: the roll is just like any other places.

A large sake is the equivalent to a size small to the rest of the other sushi restaurants. 

I would say this place is. Where you want to go if you want to impress your date. Not recommending this place to family. They don't have karage or kid friendly meals. But speaking of which, since they don't serve any karage and my son is a very picky eater. We had some left over fried chicken from lunch and they were kind enough to warm it up so my son could eat them. Bc he would not eat cold or room temperature chicken.  It worked out bc we didn't have to leave or rush our dinner. So happy they were being very accommodating.
author: Hollie H.

description:
YAAAASSS! New go-to sushi place to curb my sushi craving!

As all the other reviewers have mentioned, Elephant Sushi is rather small with around 12-15 seats at the sushi bar. There's almost always a line before the place opens at 5pm and fills up immediately. Service is fast and as long as people aren't chitchattying for too long, you probably won't have to wait longer than 30 mins. Good news - there's a lot of bars around the area you can grab a quick drink at.

I'd trust what other Yelpers have posted in the photos section - since I followed their advice and couldn't have made a better choice myself. So yeah, get the Ya Man roll and Yummy Pocket. The Ya Man roll ($13) had super fresh salmon and the olive oil drizzle on top was a nice touch. The Yummy Pocket ($6) was so good I wanted to get 2 orders! At a price point of $6, it's cheaper than a lot of the maki rolls on the menu, and might I add MUCH BETTER. The sweetness of the tofu skin really complimented the spicy scallop. It was so addicting I could probably come here and order 2 of these (4 tofus hehe) and be happy. 

I wasn't completely full after the 2 items, so I opted for a negi hama (yellowtail scallion roll) as well. At $7, it was more expensive than the Yummy Pocket but maybe only half as good, if that. So I suggest stick with their specialty rolls and appetizers!

Next time I'm back, I'll def get the Yummy Pocket (duh) and probably something with uni (since I asked the guy next to me if he thought it was fresh and he said yah).
author: Sally L.

description:
Can't believe I've never written a review for my ALL TIME FAVORITE SUSHI RESTAURANT in the world. Been coming here since they opened and totally obsessed with this place. I tell everyone to come here. It's the perfect mix of AMAZING sushi in a fun trendy atmosphere. This place is perfect for date night or a small birthday dinner (they do not take parties larger than 4 and I've seen them turn many away!)

The pro tip is to get in line before they even open or else you're looking at an hour long wait. They have lines even on weekdays before they open. They've started taking reservations for the first seating so you can call for that as well. 

Everything here is amazing and they have the cheapest cocktails god knows why!! This is the only fancy sushi restaurant I've seen with $5 cocktails and they used to have $2 sake bombs like wtf they could charge $15 for a drink and no one would bat an eye. 

Staff here are all great. They look like they're having so much fun working together!!! I even had one waiter stop me while ordering and say I was ordering too much! Love it!!!!!! Everything here is delicious and the price. Is. Right.
author: Tiffany V.

description: The TL has some delicious authentic places and houses my favorite sushi spot in SF so far! My pic: Top left: white out, top right: Yama Man, Bottom left: Himalayan Trout, bottom right, Sake Nigiri.  Everything was amazing!!!  The fish was super fresh, rice was perfectly cooked and seasoned, and the flavors made my taste buds happy.  I wanted to try everything off the menu because I know it's that type of place where you can't go wrong with what you get.  Get there early or you'll be waiting outside for a while as they only have 15 seats.  With that said, service was polite and prompt.  Will be back and perhaps try the other locations.
author: Rachel M.

description:
I like elephants, and I like sushi. And when one of SF's most popular sushi bars is called Elephant Sushi, of course it becomes my favorite. (Side note: If you are looking for more restaurants ft. elephants, The Pink Elephant has bottomless mimosa brunches)

Elephant Sushi is probably among the closest you can get the intersection of amazing fish and fusiony sushi rolls. Yes, there are some places with good quality rolls, but the fish at Elephant Sushi is upscale-sushi-bar grade, and there's more thought put into their rolls than your standard rainbow/caterpillar/dragon. 

We started off with a complimentary appetizer of butterfish with ponzu, a simple yet decadent combination of textures and flavors. 

Our favorite was the popular YA MAN ROLL ($13), and you can (should) describe it as sublime without sounding like an exaggerating food critic wannabe. The buttery king salmon and avocado synergize to a heavenly indulgence, and the fried red onion adds a satisfying crunchiness. The pesto and ponzu sauces blend in an intriguing contrast to finish. 

Afterwards arrive the BEASTIE BOYS ($12), another hyped item on Yelp. Remotely akin to pate, definitely requires a sophisticated palate and an acquired taste for sea urchin and monkfish liver blended with raw egg and made earthy with the nori wrap and shiso. The fancy nigiri creation is larger-than-bite-sized, but the composition with the runny yolk and oblique piece of akimo would be otherwise difficult to eat.... so my advice to my friend was "Put the whole thing in your mouth, and if it falls apart then just try to suck up the yolk so it will be less messy." I suggest asking the server for more useful insight on how to eat this.

The DOUBLE ALBACORE ($16) was another delicious roll with a lot of dimension. The subtle nuances of the albacore were enhanced by the boldly contrasting sauces of honey mustard, toasted sesame aioli, and sweet teriyaki. And avocado is always a good idea, though I wonder if one day SF will make us pay extra to add avocado to sushi rolls.

I liked how the wasabi is strong with the proper amount of masochistically satisfying nasal spiciness. You can help yourself to as much ginger as you like since it comes in a large mason jar, though I wasn't a fan of their acidic version. The novel taste is interesting at first, but I couldn't get used to my ginger tasting like it's been soaked in vinegary kombucha. 

As several reviewers have mentioned, this location is small and consists only of bar seating. The wait can get long, so I recommend getting here a few minutes before opening. There's also an awkward seat on the far left; I was right up against the wall on the side, and there was a pipe inches from my back. Essentially I could hardly move, and I don't consider myself a big person. 

I think that one seat is the only negative thing I have to say. Prices are extremely reasonable--it totaled to less than $20 per person, and this is a city where appetizers ("small plates") can cost $20. The dining experience at Elephant Sushi was memorable, and we savored the intersection of fresh fish and creative, expertly prepared rolls.
author: Edna C.

description:
3.5 stars but rounding up. Thank you, Elephant Sushi, for putting up with a few slightly buzzed (and likely mildly obnoxious) ladies storming in for a late dinner on a Thursday night! We had called earlier that night for availability for a party of 7, and they were fully booked at that time since there are only 12 seats available. However, since we left happy hour later than expected, they called us to let us know they could seat our party, and we came in around 8:45pm. Elephant Sushi has a good variety of fusion sushi rolls to choose from, and we tried:

-Himalayan Trout (New Zealand Ocean Trout, Green Onion, Spanish Chili, Garlic Ponzu, House Basil Oil, $16, https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=l6FcGOVCOhlvRxCRS8Cckw&userid=76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg): Yum! The trout was super fatty and delicious, and I loved the combination of ingredients- highly recommended!
-Hon Maguro (Sea Salted Ahi Tuna Sashimi, w/Capers, Olive Oil, Sesame Oil, Tangy Vinaigrette, Ripe Mango, $25) & Spicy Hamachi (Avocado, Jalapeño, Lime, Cucumber, Scallion, Masago, Toasted Shichimi Pepper Aioli, $15)[https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=IR_jrGdU6ROYa-ORrtqRcg&userid=76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg]: Both were very fresh, but just ok for me. I didn't like the shichimi pepper on top of the spicy hamachi roll, and wouldn't order either dish again.
-Spicy Tuna (Red Tuna Mixed in Spicy Sauce, w/Cucumber, $8, https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=g0LuYc93SVtvxC8t1qfh2w&userid=76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg): Just ok- the spicy tuna was too mushy, and I've had better versions. Skip!
-Ya Man (King Salmon, Avocado, Scallion, Fried Red Onion Chips, Pesto & Ponzu Sauce, $13): Yum- the combination of ingredients worked well together, and the fried red onion chips gave it an interesting texture. Recommended!
-Beastie Boys (Sea Urchin, Ankimo, Quail Egg, Shiso, $16): Super luxurious, and an ambitious one-biter. The combination of uni and ankimo was delicious- recommended!
-Double Albacore (White Tuna Inside & Out, Avocado, Honey Mustard, Toasted Sesame Oil, Sweet Teriyaki Sauce, $16): I loved the albacore in this roll, but I'm still unsure about the honey mustard in this. I probably wouldn't order this again, but it's worth trying once.

Although it was interesting trying some of the new combinations in the sushi rolls, I'm not sure how often I'd want to eat these flavor profiles again. For SF, the prices are about average, but a bit pricier for the portions compared to the Peninsula and South Bay. They also make the pickled ginger in house- I liked the flavor, but a lot of the slices in my jar had a lot of fibers, and it was tough to eat. Service was quick, and our food came out pretty quickly. Parking in this area can be tough, but there are street parking spots (especially a few minutes before 6pm/at 6 pm since a couple blocks have prohibited parking until then).
author: Amy D.

description:
3.7 
A really solid sushi place. Very small. Good ambience.
Your minds not going to be blown but you won't regret eating there.
The yummy pocket was super yummy.
author: Hannah J.

description:
DISSS PLACE is mucho good for people willing to try fushion sushi. worth it to get lots of rolls. (this isn't a high end quality sushi place where i would recommend sashimi or nigiri). 

reasonable prices $15~ a roll, LARGE poke bowl to share, and reasonable prices for drinks / sake. 

long wait (call ahead to find out times!) and if this one is too long, try the Elephant Sushi in Russian Hill (though I personally think this one is better)!!!
author: Cathy Y.

description:
I thought this location might be better than other one, not at all.
Super tiny place which can fit around 12 people, uncomfortable place with ok service. You can't really eat and drink need to chose one option there is no place to put plate and cup. 
No more chances for that place I'm done. 
Great place to feel uncomfortable
author: Askhat E.

description:
Pretty solid sushi although won't be a top in my list.

This location itself is VERY small (seats about 13 at the bar and seems like no place to hang a coat).

We got the Himalayan trout, ya man roll, double albacore roll, beastie boy, ankimo nigiri & toro nigiri.

My favourite was the trout. The fish was so rich and melt-in-your-mouth fatty. Rubbing the slices on the slab of Himalayan salt made them even better! Definitely a must-get item!

Ya man roll was pretty good, nice touch with the crispy onions.

Double albacore roll was disappointing. The fish was too soft like they weren't fresh. The sauce was also too strong and also too sweet.

Beastie boy was delicious! Not a fan of the ankimo (little too fishy for me) but the uni was so sweet and refreshing.

Ankimo nigiri wasn't my thing. Love monkfish liver but I guess I just don't like the taste of the ankimo itself. 

Toro nigiri wasn't bad. It was fresh, not too fatty (I'm more of a fan of super fatty tuna). The only thing was that it was too sinewy for me making certain areas of the fish harder to chew.

Customer service was decent - not great but not bad.

Enjoyed the food but I think based on prices there are better sushi places out there!
author: Shirley L.

description:
Everyone is right, this place seats exactly 12 people. Not 12 parties, 12 individual people! I definitely recommend you calling ahead to check how long the wait is, because it can get very long. Overall, I think it is worth the wait. This place is extremely small, and it has a very intimate setting (great for date night!). The ropes along the walls make it feel very nautical, while they play Bob Marley reggae music. Very cool!

We got the spicy trio sashimi bowl, which was probably the best thing we got. Great value for $18, a ton of fresh, high quality fish. I find it more similar to poke than chirashi, with awesome flavors, and great texture from the seaweed (real seaweed, not the dried kind!). We also go the spicy tuna roll and the Ya Man roll. The spicy tuna wasn't anything out of the ordinary (just very, very spicy!). The Ya man roll was pretty good, with some crunchy thing in the middle that I didn't think added much to the overall experience of eating it, but the salmon ontop was buttery and delicious.
author: Ke C.

description:
3.5/5
I've been a fan of elephant sushi since I moved to the Bay and first discovered their tiny Golden Gate location. I can't say it's as good as it used to be (taste wise about the same but missing some options I used to love and price has gone up) but it's still a solid bet if you want "fancy" sushi. The thing with Elephant Sushi is that the actual fish quality isn't all that great. The texture is too soft and there's still some taste but it's fading fast. What they are good for is their spins to the fish. They definitely add in some less-traditional ingredients but it's delicious so I can't complain. If you plan on coming here make sure you have some time because the lines can get really long. The seating is very limited (basically one long cramped sushi bar).

For my visit I got the #3 and split a Ya Man roll w/ my friend. The #3 has been my go to for a very long time because I love the capers w/ the acidity and it honestly covers up the subpar quality of the albacore quite well. I do feel like they went a bit overboard with the capers this time because the dish was a bit too salty. The walu was a bit more disappointing. The fish itself lacked flavor and the garlic pieces weren't quite enough. Rice was average and nothing special. (3.5/5)

The Ya Man roll seems to have everyone raving and while I can't say it's the best roll ever I did enjoy it. It's a pretty roll and none of the ingredients stand out too much but as a whole bite it's quite tasty. There are other options I would like to try but if you definitely want to get a roll this is a safe bet (4/5)

My friend got the #2 and enjoyed it but said her rice was soggy. I didn't try it so nothing else I can note.

Overall, my experience here didn't quite live up to my original memories of Elephant Sushi but the price still isn't awful, their flavors are good, and I'd probably still return (if there's no wait).
author: Vivian C.

description: This is definitely the best place to eat sushi within the city. There is usually a cue which will make you wait 30min but it totally worth it. Pick this place if you are too lazy to make a reservation to a place in advance for the Friday night.
author: Ilker D.

description: This place keeps fresh sushi and the sushi is made right in front of you.  The venue is small, but the decor is pretty cool, and it adds to the element that everyone is close together.  The sushi is created upon order and takes no time to make.  The food is really good, and the saki was great too.
author: Bradley S.

description:
There is a lot to like about Elephant Sushi; if I could, I would give it 3.5 stars.  Unlike other sushi restaurants, the small spaces allows you to enjoy your sushi in an intimate setting.  It's a small restaurant with limited bar seating, so be prepared to wait if you are visiting during prime dinner hours.  My friend and I went on a weekend evening, and it took about a 20-30 minutes to seat 2 people.  There is a bar nearby if you need a place to wait out, and they will call you once your seats are available.

Overall, I think the fish was excellent; from the Hamachi Truffle to the nigiri/sushi, I though all the fish I sampled had a fresh and buttery quality that I enjoyed.  They offered a sample of the Hamachi Truffle, and if you like truffle flavors, you will really like this dish.  While I'm not a truffle fanatic, I appreciated how the seared yellowtail combined with the oil, ponzu, garlic, and scallion bits.  The maguro nigiri was sizable; they do not skimp on the fish here! 

However, the size of their items turned out to be a downside when it came to their sushi.  It's true what they say: size does matter, and I felt like the huge sushi cuts were harkening a bit too closely to the elephant referenced in the restaurant's name.  I tried the Ya Man roll, and while I thought the salmon, avocado, and other assorted ingredients practically melted in my mouth, the sections were falling apart and seemed ginormous.  If I go again, I think I will stick to the other items, since my friend really enjoyed her rice bowl and the appetizers looked interesting.
author: Keith H.

description: This location of Elephant sushi is smaller than the one on Hyde street but I really liked the service here. The only downside of this location is that they don't serve the flaming sea bass sushi. However, the sushi menu here was really good. We got the yaman roll, red and yellow roll and the butter shush roll. All three rolls were exceptional. We also ordered the spicey squid (it's really spicey!)
author: Deki T.

description:
My favorite sushi spot in SF. All of the fish is very fresh and the service is great. 

Get there early to avoid waiting in a long line!
author: Jacob O.

description: This is the perfect place to have a  really exceptional sashimi, sushi and rolls, you will eat them listening to reggae music, odd but great. The girls doing the service are very organized and super nice. Price is higher than any other sushi place but it is really worth it and the wait is worth it too.
author: Jacques H.

description:
This place is great. Found it as a recommended sushi spot on Yelp and it did not disappoint. The portions are huge compared to other sushi places and the fish quality is excellent. I had the omakase sashimi, the yummy basket, the beastie boys and a nigiri of the ocean trout. All of the dishes were great and the prices were very affordable compared to other sushi places in the city.  They have an interesting take on ginger too. 

They also have 4 different types of 'sashimi bowls' (basically chirashi). The place is really small and takes no reservations so get in early. A line forms around 30 minutes before they open. Service was also good.
author: Andrew S.

description:
Elephant Sushi is a minuscule sushi joint in the Tenderloin, but don't let that deter you! Their fish is amazingly fresh and they are very generous with their sashimi slices. 

I ordered one of their chirashi bowls (can't remember the name but it had 3 types of spicy fish and avocado) and I was very very satiated by the sheer amount of fish they provided. It has my favorite: salmon, and I simply loved how fresh it tasted. The chirashi is definitely worth the $18 in my opinion.

A fair warning though: since there are only a dozen so seats in the restaurant, the wait can get quite long. I would recommend coming right when it opens, putting down your name, and heading out to a couple bars in the area to mull your time over with friends. That being said, the service there is impeccable and they are very, very efficient.
author: Allison T.

description:
The place was small but had an intimate feel. Only waited for about 15 minutes for a Sunday dinner. 

My boyfriend and I ordered the Ya Man roll, yummy pockets, Double albacore roll, and the Beastie Boys. Wish we had the Ya Man roll and yummy pockets last.. they were soooo good! The Ya Man roll might have been one of the best rolls I've ever had! Salmon just melts in your mouth (drool). The Beastie Boys were okay to me, just over priced and had too much rice. The Double Albacore is where the place lost one star.. it had wayyyy to much rice on it and the rice was a soggy mushy mess. We ended up just eating the fish off of it and throwing away the rice, and even then the fish wasn't that good. Wouldn't recommend this roll. 

Overall the experience was pretty good, fish was fresh! Just order the Ya Man roll!!!
author: Michelle L.

description: Great Fusion well done, I really like my late night Dinner. Sketchy area, be Street Smart.
author: Dave R.

description:
Was looking forward to this place due to great reviews. 

Experience killed by the setting. Just a long low bar with low uncomfortable stools, no leg room and just enough space for a small plate. 

The sashimi tuna was really tasty! Really!

The rolls we had were mixed and the choice was not inspiring. Two were really good three were bland

Nice touch with the ginger in a jar. Not standard at all and tasty!

Would have been an easy 4 but for the seating and table. Cramped and uncomfortable. Not a keeper
author: Dave H.

description: I wish this place was in Chicago! I loved it that much! Their flavors are unique like the salmon sashimi with truffle oil. We also had one of the special poke bowls which was incredible. It's a tiny place with literally just a sushi bar so go early or make a reservation.
author: Lotus Y.

description:
Another 3.5 for me-- I thought the food was fairly good and obviously very fresh but I didn't LOVE it, except for the walu carpaccio, which tasted (both oddly and deliciously) like ribeye steak. Tonight, the orders seemed to be dominated by rolls.

Arrived about 15 minutes early and there were a couple people around, but no line (which is surprising given the reviews on this spot). We got seated at the small bar (the only available seating at this maybe 15 person restaurant). They offered a taste of the walu carpaccio, which the bf and I both enjoyed. It really did taste like ribeye! Super weird! The bf is a fish...hater but he said he'd eat fish every day if it tasted like this.

I got the Ya Man (I just realized it's supposed to be like "yeah, man!"...I forget people spell "yeah" that way. It was okay...the fish was very fresh and they definitely had added some sort of salt to it (which I really like). Wouldn't call it buttery but definitely melts in your mouth. The red onion chips didn't really taste like onion chips-- more like stale-ish crispy things in your sushi. The pesto sauce was more like basil-flavored olive oil, didn't even notice it until I asked. Not bad, but not amazing.

The bf got a spicy tuna roll: standard, but you could tell the fish was very fresh. Their spicy tuna is cut up and mixed, but not into the mush / goo that other spicy tuna rolls are. You can still tell it's fish.

Tried out our friends' rainbow roll and spicy hamachi roll. Again, fish was fresh but I feel like the fish taste gets lost in rolls. Sad. 

I'll definitely be back at some point to try out the Himalayan trout served on a giant salt block!
author: Nicole H.

description: If you're in the mood for western style sushi this is definitely a place you need to hit up. I've been to the tenderloin location on numerous occasions and there is always a line. It's only sushi bar style and there are naturally a limited number of seats. A good tip is to go to the bar, RX, next-door and have a drink while you wait. The staff over there is really nice and welcome people who are waiting for their table. Their westernize sushi roll offerings are tasty and the staff is great. Prices are fair for the area-just don't go there expecting an authentic Japanese sushi experience.
author: Robert C.

description:
This may be my favorite sushi place in San Francisco. First, let me give a disclaimer: I hail from good 'ole Nevada, where the only way you eat sushi is all-you-can-eat-style. Aka my standards are pretty low. Now that I live in the Bay, I've gotten used to the higher quality sushi, but this place by far exceeds all expectations.

We tried 6 rolls and all of them were good. All of them. There were some strange ingredients like pesto or Dijon mustard. Who would have known this is what my sushi has been missing the entire time?! Holy cow. Get the Double Albacore roll for sure- the butter fish is, as the name suggests, buttery and delicious. Second favorite was the Ya Man. 

Sadly there is just a bar here, no tables, so seating is very limited. Get there right at 6 when they open and so you can also secure a parking spot right in front just in time for free meters!
author: Steph D.

description:
This restaurant is in a very nice area of SF in a great neighborhood and very cozy feeling. To be fair with my review this was the first and only time I'll ever eat at this place, so take this review with a grain of salt. I have a feeling that if you are a local/regular your experience will be different. 

I ordered the 16 piece assorted sashimi and here is the breakdown of the items presented to me. 

4 pieces salmon
4 pieces Ahi
4 pieces white fish (seared)
1 scallop cut in half 
2 pieces yellowtail 
2 piece sea bass 

As stated this is a nice neighborhood, thus expensive - $40. 

They have several things on the menu like bluefin, toro, and various other things that did not appear on my plate of " assorted" sashimi. No mackerel, octopus, roe, or anything else. 

I think they loaded me up on the cheap and/or stuff they wanted to get rid of. 

Basically no value in this place. My guess is if you are a regular there may be nicer options, but if you are a traveler like me I would definitely stay away from this place. 

The restaurant itself is small and nothing special, staff was friendly.
author: Thomas H.

description:
Small small place. I definitely had this place bookmarked when I saw a long line out the door while waiting for Mensho which is close by. 

I'm not even 100% I remember what we ordered, but everything was delicious!

It felt a bit packed when we were eating especially when everything ended up coming at around the same time. However, it was great, fresh sushi and Stef C and I had a great time. 

Protip: get there early so you don't have to wait.
author: Nina Y.

description:
Came here recently with a friend and really enjoyed my meal here. In general I haven't been too impressed with the sushi scene in SF (not your $$$$ places but the more casual places), but since my friend spoke so highly of this place, I thought I'd check it out. 

We arrived maybe 5 minutes before they opened at 6 on a Sunday and they were already seating people. I haven't been to the other locations, but this spot is really small. There is only bar seating and the whole place seats maybe 15-20 people, so I would recommend coming right when they open if you want to avoid a wait.

The seats aren't that big and don't have a back, so ladies if you have any jackets or purses, they do have some small hooks underneath the bar where you can hang your stuff. 

My friend and I split the sashimi omakase (16 pieces for $40) and we each ordered the Ya Man Roll (king salmon, avocado, scallion, fried red onion chips, pesto and ponzu sauce) since my friend highly recommended this role. Plus I was intrigued by the idea of pesto in sushi so I decided to try it out.

The sashimi selection was pretty good. I don't remember everything on the plate, but there was hamachi, tuna, salmon, scallops, and chutoro plus two more fish. The fish tasted pretty fresh but nothing mindblowing. There were definitely some my friend and I liked better than others, but that comes down to a matter of personal taste. 

The Ya Man Roll was my favorite part of the meal. I couldn't actually taste the pesto in the roll, but everything was flavored very well (I think the salmon might have had some salt added to it?) and all the different flavors and textures came together very well. I was pleasantly surprised by how much I enjoyed this roll and definitely want to come back for it again.

Parking in this area is all street parking and it's pretty tough to find, so I would recommend not driving if possible.

I paid ~$45 for this meal.
author: Dianna H.

description: The restaurant is very small. Nice setting... but if you really value your personal space you may not enjoy your time here. I came here on a Friday evening and the wait wasn't terribly long around 6pm. As for the sushi, nothing stood out to me in particular, but it tasted fresh and was presented nicely. My girlfriend and I split 3 rolls between the two of us and it seemed to do the trick!
author: Andrew A.

description:
I'm not going to lie some of the sushi tasted unfresh and funky.

Let's start off with the spicy tuna roll with the seaweed in it that adds a weird sour taste to the already bitter stating tuna that day. Not sure if the tuna was unfresh that day but everything that we had that had tuna tasted a bit off.

The hamachi truffle was okay but the truffle sauce was overpowering. If you think you can't get overpowered by truffle oil, come try a bite of this.

The blue fine bites, once again with that tuna tasted unfresh so we sent it back.

The chip and dips with the tuna and garlic chips were the worst. It was like a Costco tuna sample with pita garlic chips, no thanks. We ended up not even eating this dish.

The ankimo and quail egg were the best thing at this place that we tried, along with the sea bass sashimi.

The service is slow, and there's usually a line out the door since they have limited seating.

For the wait, the price, and the quality and taste of the food we had for around $150, I'd say 3 stars.
author: Jack R.

description: The sushi is amazing. You taste every element and it all tastes fresh. Found this by accident and I am more than satisfied.
author: Dmitriy V.

description:
Yummmm first time at elephant sushi and it did not disappoint.

This place is super tiny so try to call right before they open to get your name on the list.
author: Vivian W.

description: As of now, this is my favorite sushi place in all of San Francisco. The atmosphere is first really nice.  Good for small groups or dates. But more importantly, the food. We tried a bunch of rolls and all were delicious. Faves were naked scallop and Alaska roll. We also tried some of the sashimi. Highlight was the Redfin tuna. As for nigiri, the ponzu salmon was fantastic. For the most part, dishes are creative but they focus on simplicity still and quality ingredients. Overall, I would keep coming back for sushi.
author: Grace A.

description: Definitely not the best sushi I've ever eaten but probably in my Top 5.  There's nothing on the menu that is unique, but what they lack in uniqueness and presentation they make up for in quality.  This is a tiny spot, seating only a dozen people.  We got there right when it opened so we didn't have to wait.  But even if there is a line you won't wait very long.  These guys roll really fast; definitely the fastest I've ever experienced.  We ordered, ate, and paid within a 1/2 hour tops.
author: Drew M.

description: Great ambience, melts in your mouth sushi and nice service.  Quaint location, lucky we got to sit at the 8 person bar
author: Joe Z.

description:
I really enjoyed my dinner it. It's a very small restaurant, so you should definitely call in and make a reservation. Once we got in here, we were given a little piece of butterfish to try. And this was amazing!!! Some of the best fish I've ever had. I then ordered the sushi roll with butterfish on it (White Out, I think) and it was also delicious. *However, afterwards my friend and I Googled butterfish since we loved it but had never had it before and there were articles on Google about it being banned because it causes diarhea... I personally didn't find this to be a problem afterward though!* 

Besides the butterfish, which was honestly so amazing, I had the tofu pocket appetizer, which was good, as well as the tuna and chips appetizer, again which was good. The people here were super nice and service was fast!
author: Caley Z.

description:
Some of the best sushi I've had. 

The space is super small, with just seating at the perimeter of the sushi bar. But the service is super personal and my waiter was passionate about the food and able to make some very good recommendations. 

Everything was melt-in-mouth fresh and amazing. 

Pro tip: it says they close at 9:30, but last call is 9:10, much to my disappointment the 2nd time I tried to go.
author: Robert K.

description:
One word...AMAZING. As a fair-weather fan of fish, this place made me love fish in ways I didn't even know were possible. With one bite of the White Out Roll, this instantly became my favorite sushi spot in SF. Along with the Yummy pocket, Spicy Tuna, and Ya Man roll, every bite had a very distinct and unique flavor that made me want to go back for more. The fish was so buttery and smooth, it really blew me away. 

We came with a group of 3 and had to wait about 20 minutes for a spot at the sushi bar to open up. The inside was playing some incredible music, good vibe and energy to the place. If you have to wait, they take your phone number down to call you when your seats are ready. Probably not the best place for a big group, for a cute date idea, this place should win you some brownie points. 

KEEP IN MIND... there is only SUSHI BAR SEATING.
author: Paolo B.

description:
I hate to say I judged this book by its cover.  The name "Elephant Sushi" didn't exactly scream out AMAZING SUSHI to me.  But after my dinner there, I am now echo-ing the sentiments of my friends.  Elephant Sushi is pretty amazing!  We came near the end of the night and were the last seating.  It was about a 25 minutes wait and we just went next door to Rx for a drink (I highly recommend getting a drink at Rx regardless if you have a wait or not).

Elephant Sushi has just one row of seating, which I noticed is very SF.  So expect a wait time, which is ALSO very SF.  I wish I can find another word to describe my experience here.  But like many of my other SF reviews, Elephant Sushi is also FRESH TO DEATH.  The restaurant is very trendy and intimate (may be due to the lack of space).  My friend loves their Mussels Shooters here, but they were not on the menu unfortunately.  Restaurants running out of their most popular dishes is a central theme to eating in SF.  I guess that just forces me to come back next time.

Recommended:
1. Monk Fish Liver:  Sashimi style; the pieces are so generous.
2. HIMALAYAN OCEAN TROUT:  I can eat this every day.  The moment it was served on the pink rock salt plate, I was in love.  The salt plate gave it just enough kick so you don't need soy sauce.  The ocean trout is so fresh and so orange, I love it, love it!
3. Hamachi Truffle:  Truffle anything is good
4. Beastie Boys:  I love this type of combination.  Bring on the liver, the eggs, the uni.
author: Carrie L.

description: Terrific sushi. The thickest slices of fish I've ever seen. Very small but worth the wait. Terrific quality and value.
author: Mike H.

description:
Definitely my go to sushi spot in San Francisco. 

This location, unlike Hyde Street, only has about 15 seats around the bar. 

Service is always awesome. Be sure to get there early, or be ready to put your name in and head down the street to Jones or Redford for a drink while you wait. 

Their Sashimi and Nigiri (Ocean Trout, Sake, and Maguro are the favorite) are great on their own, but be sure to get the Chips and Dip to start.
author: Greg E.

description:
super glad that i took wifey here last night! ive been to the original location in nob/russian hill years ago, and was only mildly impressed back then. but wifey is keen on sushi and this is pretty close to shakedown (she's also keen on ice cream) so this was it! we were first in line on wednesday evening, 5 minutes before they opened. YASSS. 

the restaurant is tiny! it's only the sushi bar, which suits us just fine. pretty extensive menu though for such a small space.  appetizers, house specials, sashimi, rolls, and good selections for nigiri. beer, wine and sake only - suited us just fine :)

they offered us escolar from the chef to start - a perfect bite! we ordered: beastie boys, omakase sashimi (16 pieces for $40), spicy scallop in inari (2x), and a lot of salmon nigiri (and toro and others). everything was pretty bomb! and the prices are reasonable. the ladies who work here are also super sweet and take care of you really well. i'd def come back for a casual dinner outing, or by myself!
author: Christina L.

description:
I wanted to love this place. It's a small, cozy sushi bar and reminded me of the tiny sushi counters in Tokyo. 

But they started off on the wrong foot. They told us the wait would be 5 minutes. More like 45 minutes!! I felt like it was a scam to get us to wait. I spoke to other people and the same thing happened to them. 

If I'm going to wait 45 minutes for food, it better be amazing or cheap, or cheap AND amazing. The food is good, but not worth the wait, and definitely not cheap.
author: Meredith M.

description: This place is a joke! The fish quality is ok but the flavors and service? Someone seriously dropped the ball. Truffle oil on everything! Yuk! Truffle oil can be tasty but it isn't meant to accompany every food. Very disappointed and to top it off I was presented with a check that had tip options of 20% 25% and 30% Lmaof! 15% simply because you're pompous! Typically I leave a %20 tip but ask for %30 and you can kiss my tip!! So won't be back! Head up the hill for real sushi and leave this swill behind.
author: Kellen M.

description:
Those who know me know that there are very few places in SF that I think are excellent. Elephant Sushi has always been a reliable choice for me. This was my first time at the new location on Geary and it turned out to be way smaller than I expected. We arrived at 6:30 on Friday evening and luckily we waited only 20 minutes to get seated. 

The menu here is more limited than at the Hyde Street location and the seating is tight and somewhat awkward. However, the food was amazing like always. The truffle oil on the White Out Roll made it spectacular. The Rainbow Roll was a feast for the hungry eyes and belly. The Bestie Boys was rich and luxurious. And the Salmon nigiri sushi was melt-in-you-mouth delicious.
author: Yi Z.

description: Wow this place was great! Really intimate sushi bar setting and all of the food was delicious. We got the Himalayan Trout, basil salmon nigiri, White out roll, and the ya man roll. Our favorites were the basil salmon nigiri and the white out roll. Whatever they put on it was amazing. Service was also really good.
author: Mary W.

description:
There is a very limited seating inside - just about a dozen or so seats around the bar. The workers are very attentive and helpful, and the interior deco is lux and nice. dark lighting. 

We ordered the himalayan trout, ya man roll, some nigiri and some caprese fusion sashimi. But oh man. The sashimi was amazing. melts in your mouth, super fatty for the salmon, and it makes you want to empty out your wallet to get more of those fish pieces. But each of the sashimi dishes comes with six pieces, and run 17-25$ ish a plate, so. empty out some wallets if you want to get full here.
author: Grace P.

description:
Yummmmmmmy.

My friend and I arrived on a Friday night around 6pm. Took us awhile to find parking, and the wait was about an hour. I recommend making a reservation before hand. They gave us a call once a table opened up for us.

To our surprise, this restaurant was really cozy, seating only about 12 people. For 2, we ordered Ya Man Roll, White out roll, and Himalayan trout. Every party we saw ordered a Ya Man Roll, which was the real reason why I ordered it and I do not regret it at all. The 2 rolls we ordered were delicious, the fish was fresh and the rolls both had an interesting sweet taste to it. The himalayan trout was good, but I did not fall in love. Maybe because I expected a lot from the amazing reviews. I would definitely recommend to try it because it has such an interesting concept since it is served on a salt block.

TL;DR: Definitely try Ya Man roll and White out roll!!
author: Shirley S.

description:
I recently read an empowering article from a woman who decided that she was going to date herself. On Saturday nights, she would treat herself to a nice dinner at one of the hottest new restaurant in the city. The benefits of dining alone: you don't have to depend on anyone, you can pick whatever restaurant you want to go to, and order whatever the phuck you want. 

Sounds great to me except I have an irrational fear of dining alone. Remember that depressing [dinner alone] scene from "Forgetting Sarah Marshall": http://youtu.be/sBcWR_fArKM? Welp, I would need to romance the bottle before attempting that. 

After some reassurance from friends that I wouldn't look like a loser (yes, I know this is ridiculous but my middle name is self-conscious) and googling random articles about eating alone, I worked up enough courage and decided I was going to hit up Elephant Sushi's newest location in TL...alone for lunch. 

However, the day of, my friend asked what I was doing. I told him where I was going and he said, he wanted to join so we can catch up. 

I am SO glad that he came. Not because it saved me from dining alone but because I was able to sample a lot more things than I would have alone. 

I've never been to the original and wildly popular Elephant Sushi location in Russian Hill (http://www.yelp.com/biz/elephant-sushi-san-francisco)--I wrongly assumed it was sushi for yuppies. Their newest location (soft opened 12/1/15) in TL has a combo of both menus from their other locations. On the menu you will find fusiony apps and sashimi dishes, sashimi salad, sashimi bowls, sashimi, nigiri, and rolls. Online reports said there's omakase; there's only omakase for sashimi (16 pc - $40). Beer, wine, and sake only. There's only 12 seats and there's no reservations. I highly recommend coming alone or with one other person only. If you don't want to wait hours for dinner (we were told there was a 3 hour wait last night), come during lunch. 

I'm not a fan of fusiony Japanese sushi or rolls but Elephant Sushi is legit for Americanized Japanese sushi. They use high quality ingredients unlike your run-of-the-mill Japanese restaurants in SF. The only drawback is they don't have a large selection of fish because they serve only wild or sustainable seafood. They also pickle their own ginger, make their own low sodium soy, and use real wasabi root!

My friend and I ordered the following (everything was solid but below is a list from our favorite to least favorite items): 
*Beastie Boys: Ankimo, uni, quail egg nigiri (2 pc - $12): http://bit.ly/1SzCSlv
*Ya Man Roll: King salmon, avocado, scallion, fried red onion chips, pesto, ponzu ($13): http://bit.ly/1QhvY5e
*Himalayan Trout: New Zealand ocean trout, green onion, Spanish chili, garlic ponzu, house basil oil ($16): http://bit.ly/1lbwHtr
*Vodka Marinated Ankimo Nigiri (2 pc - $7): http://bit.ly/1lbx9rR
*Basil Sake Nigiri (2 pc - $8): http://bit.ly/1lZAR7O
*Hamachi Nigiri (2 pc - $7): http://bit.ly/1YKSLcx
*Maguro Nigiri (2 pc - $8): http://bit.ly/1N5DMTh
*Hamachi Truffle: Seared yellowtail, truffle oil, fried garlic chips, ponzu, scallion ($20): http://bit.ly/1SzD2cF

We went a little crazy with the fatty omega-3 fishes (salmon and ocean trout) but damn were they super fresh and buttery. 

The Beastie Boys is a must order--a menage a trois of decadently creamy ankimo, sweetly briny uni, and silky yolk. 

As much as I like authentic sushi, I get roll cravings from time to time and the Ya Man thoroughly satisfied it. Great combo of textures from the buttery salmon, avocado and onion chips. I like that Tamir (owner/sushi chef) doesn't use too much rice and doesn't skimp on the neta topping; it covers the entire roll. 

The Himalayan trout was beautifully presented and the silky pieces of sashimi were like a umami fish butter; great with sake.

The nigiris were all solid but the ankimo was my favorite. Like foie gras of the sea, the housemade ankimo that was marinated with vodka had a sinfully rich texture. The shari was nicely seasoned and compact so you can finish in one bite.

I love truffle but it overpowered the hamachi so I would skip the Hamachi Truffle next time. 

Oh yah, I couldn't get enough of their house pickled ginger as a palate cleanser: http://bit.ly/1IrwexA. I almost finished half of a jar myself. =/

Elephant Sushi is family owned and they take pride in ensuring that they don't serve mediocre sushi which is why all their locations are tiny (one sushi chef only). Tamir and his wife (who runs the front of the house) were very hospitable, engaging, and attentive. 

Minimalist ambiance with just a sushi counter so I can't stress enough to don't come with more than another person. There's no space inside to wait. 

Parking is much easier than their original location especially during lunch. 

I'm a omakase whore so I hope Elephant Sushi considers adding omakase nigiri in the future. Kanpai!
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
Okay to be real, I came here on a super special night (my girl taking me out for my bday) which was a super thoughtful night. The place is perfect for that nice, intimate night out with your significant other. Reason being because they are a super small restaurant with only a handful of seats available at their sushi bar. 
I give them 3-Stars because the hype is a little too much. I admit, they have some really great flavor combos, the trout sashimi on the salt board was amazing, but the pricing can be a bit lower than what it's priced at. Other than that dish, the rest was okay. They have great presentation with their dishes, and truly have some unique dishes. But honestly, don't go in their hungry because you will leave and want to order a slice of pizza from across the street. On any note! 
I definitely will go back though (when I get a bonus check) because there are a few dishes I really wanted to try, but damn you have to be either rich or saving up for that night to get what you want plus more. My girl did a great job making the selections on the menu, so overall I left happy knowing we got to try some of the things we went for. 
But if you know me, you know my ratings are highly based upon service, and let me just say this again, it's no more than 15 people in that restaurant so there is no excuse to missing orders or being slow to get to people, either with their food or their orders. The server that night was probably just off her game, but no excuses when you are paying that kind of money to eat out at a heavily hyped spot. One being that the people behind the counter are helping out with serving, just like any other sushi bar setting. Two, when you call out for the server and they respond that they'll be right there, I expect them to come right after they do what they were doing prior to your call out. But no, she failed to tend to our calls all night. We even waited for one of our dishes for half an hour. That's after we put in the order, and asked about it twice. AND IT WAS THE TROUT SASHIMI! 
But like I said, I'll give them another shot. Probably for a casual date with my girl, but nothing more than another shot and to get some of the items we missed as well as some new menu items.
author: Nick A.

description:
Got here at 4:45 PM and I was the first one in line. A little after that a long line started to form. The service was fast and friendly. Bar seating only for about 12 people.

It's so nice that they start you off with some Walu carpaccio for you to try. I didn't know this, so I actually ordered a whole plate, but it was so good. 

Himalayan salt trout-this was one of my favorites. The trout comes on top of a Himalayan salt block. The flavors really come through

Spicy scallop tofu pockets-a bit hard to eat, but another thumbs up. Usually these tofus are stuff with rice. It's nice to see something different. The spicy and sweetness go well together.

Beastie Boys w/ Ankimo, uni, quail egg nigiri-they give a decent amount of Uni. Not a Uni fan at all, but everything goes well together. Love the Ankimo. 

I should have listened to the waitress and get one of their popular rolls, but instead we picked the spicy hamachi roll. Nothing special at all. Decent size, but this is a pass.

Albacore tataki-this also came on top of a Himalayan salt block, but with lots of jalapeno, basil, and tomatoes. Sounds like a weird combo, but it wasn't bad at all. Very interesting in a good way. Super stuff after this. 

I will be back. Price is very reasonable. They also don't seat parties of more than 4.
author: Karen H.

description:
One of my new favorite sushi places. The fish was extremely fresh, they had House made ginger, the vibe was very trendy and they limited sale menu was a good one.
We split the fish and chips, rainbow roll, and the roll that just about every other table had which was the one that they lit on fire. I enjoyed erything and appreciated the fresh flavors. 
Whatever you order, make sure you start with the fish and chips!
author: Tricia G.

description:
Elephant Sushi has good reviews on Yelp and really appealing photos, but I was overall disappointed by my experience. 

I came here on a Friday night and waited about 30 minutes to be seated. The inside is super small -- they can only accommodate around 10 people at a time. I ordered their "Ya Man Roll," which was decent. There was a fair amount of "dressing" on it (including oils, etc.), so it was hard for the actual flavor of the salmon to shine through. The roll itself is also on the smaller side (maybe about 6-7 thinly cut pieces), so at ~$18 for just the roll post-tax + tip, it's definitely on the pricier side. 

Service was decent, given the cramped space. They also have a ginger jar that you can help yourself to, which was quite good. Unless I'm in the area and really craving Japanese, I most likely won't come back again.
author: Jackie Y.

description: Tiny spot with amazing flavors and exceptionally fresh fish.  Decadent...fatty tuna with shaved truffle...really, need I say more.  Service is spot on withput being overbearing.  Don't miss it!!
author: foodygrl s.

description:
I have been waiting for this location to open up. And it finally did! This place is so unique on its own and I am so happy to come before the weights begin. Try to come ASAP before the wait is super long. The place only seats 12 in the entire place. So you can imagine how long the wait can be. 

Try to mussel shooters. It's so creative and really good. We also got the red and yellow roll, Yummy pocket, saki sashimi and hotate nigiri. Everything is so delicious that I can't describe how satisfied I was leaving this place. The salmon melts in your mouth, however it does come slightly dressed in a sauce for a sashimi. The Yummy pocket is spicy and fresh.  The service is great and the atmosphere/music/decoration is awesome. The ginger is fresh ginger, so no fake stuff here. 

They call me by my name every time a dish is ready and handed directly to me from the chef  fan girl status for this place. I Totally will be coming here all the time. Good sushi place right around the corner from my place.
author: Jackie N.

description:
Sushi has two distinct conflicting flavor profiles.

Either you do it traditionally where you know the skill and can bring out the flavor in the meat. 

Or you go for a mix of flavors that lead to an interesting and delicious flavor profile.

Elephant does both. The Red & Yellow Sushi is a delicious flavor profile that produces interesting flavors. The tuna rolls are delicious the sashimi bowl is just great fish & rice.
author: Rohan D.

description:
Small place (10 seats?), and be prepared to wait. Thankfully, you add your number to the sign in sheet and they will call you when your seat is available! 

The quality here is outstanding. Even the ginger is house made instead of that store bought stuff that you find at many sushi places. 

While not quite traditional Japanese Sushi, it's working with some creativity, high quality ingredients, and tender love and care.
author: Leo I.

description:
This place is one of the very best sushi places I have been to in my life. Although pricey, it's really reasonable considering 1) sushi is always pricey 2) the quality is exceptional. Like, so much so, the price is a steal. Truly a small gem of the city. The place is tiny though, so not great for groups but good for dates!
Warning: the spicy tuna is pretty darn spicy.
